How Sexist Marketing Led to a Wider Gender Gap in the Technology Industry
Commodore 64 Personal Computer Advertisement 1985
After World War II, women dominated the computer programming environment. At the height of the Space Race, employed by organizations such as NASA, they were quite literally called “computers”, being in charge of calculations and programming the massive machines. So, what happened? Why is the computer science and information technology space dominated by men right now?

During my research, I’ve found that the answer points back to the popularization of the personal computer and how it was mainly marketed to little boys. In contrast, parents were encouraged to buy their daughters dolls and easy bake ovens. As you can see in this commodore advertisement from 1985, the main user of the PC is an all-American little boy.
Margaret Hamilton 1969
The image to the left is a photograph from 1969. Margaret Hamilton and her team were in charge of writing all of the assembly code for the Apollo 11 mission. The photograph shows her standing with all of the software created for the iconic space mission.
Univac Computer in the 1950s.
Both versions convey a topic; it’s pretty easy to predict that the paragraph will be about epidemiological evidence, but only the second version establishes an argumentative point and puts it in context. The paragraph doesn’t just describe the epidemiological evidence; it shows how epidemiology is telling the same story as etiology. Similarly, while Version A doesn’t relate to anything in particular, Version B immediately suggests that the prior paragraph addresses the biological pathway (i.e. etiology) of a disease and that the new paragraph will bolster the emerging hypothesis with a different kind of evidence. As a reader, it’s easy to keep track of how the paragraph about cells and chemicals and such relates to the paragraph about populations in different places.
Easy Bake Oven Advertisement 1981
Both versions convey a topic; it’s pretty easy to predict that the paragraph will be about epidemiological evidence, but only the second version establishes an argumentative point and puts it in context. The paragraph doesn’t just describe the epidemiological evidence; it shows how epidemiology is telling the same story as etiology. Similarly, while Version A doesn’t relate to anything in particular, Version B immediately suggests that the prior paragraph addresses the biological pathway (i.e. etiology) of a disease and that the new paragraph will bolster the emerging hypothesis with a different kind of evidence. As a reader, it’s easy to keep track of how the paragraph about cells and chemicals and such relates to the paragraph about populations in different places.
Apple II Advertisement 1985
The ad, shows Brian Scott an American little boy with big dreams of becoming an astronaut. The Apple II is the tool he needs to help him achieve those ambitions. In the ad, you can even see him mess with his female classmate as she uses the product.
This plot was created with data from The National Center for Education Statistics
As you can see the gender gap widens after 1995. It is important to keep in mind that the Computer Science Bachelor may not have been popular in the early days of computing, so this plot starts 1970. However, advertisements in the 70s and 80s may have deterred more women from even considering the major in later decades.

What does this tell us about American Capitalism? What can we learn about gender roles in our society?
